Questions.Question: What is the relationship between charged bodies?
Questions.Answer:
Like charges repel, and unlike charges attract with a force directly proportional to the product of
their charges and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.

Questions.Question: What is the purpose of a cell?
Questions.Answer: A cell is a device that converts chemical energy to electrical energy.

Questions.Question: What are the three parts of a cell?
Questions.Answer: The electrodes, the electrolyte, and the container.

Questions.Question: What is the purpose of each of the three parts of a cell?
Questions.Answer:
The electrodes are the current conductors of the cell. The electrolyte is the solution that acts upon 
the electrodes. The container holds the electrolyte and provides a means of mounting the 
electrodes.

Gist: the solution that acts upon the electrodes

What is the main difference between the two types of cells?

The secondary cell can be restored to its original condition by an electric current. The primary cell 
cannot.

Questions.Answer: The process of converting chemical energy into electrical energy.

Questions.Question:
When using Kirchhoff’s voltage law, how are voltage polarities assigned to the voltage drops
across resistors?
Questions.Answer:
The point at which current enters the resistor is assigned a negative polarity and the point at which
current leaves the resistor is assigned a positive polarity.

A circuit has a source voltage of 100 volts and two 50-ohm resistors connected in series. If the
reference point for this circuit is placed between the two resistors, what would be the voltage at
the reference point?

If the reference point in question 25 were connected to ground, what would be the voltage level of
the reference point?
What is an open circuit?
Questions.Answer: A circuit where there is no longer a complete path for current flow.

Questions.Question: What is a short circuit?
Questions.Answer: An accidental path of low resistance which passes an abnormally high amount of current.

Questions.Question: Why will a meter indicate more voltage at the battery terminal when the battery is out of a circuit
Questions.Answer: The internal (source) resistance of the battery will drop some of the voltage.

Questions.Question: What condition gives maximum power transfer from the source to the load?
Questions.Answer: When the load resistance equals the source resistance.

Questions.Question: Define inductance.
Questions.Answer: Inductance is the property of a coil (or circuit) which opposes any CHANGE in current.

Questions.Question: What is meant by induced emf? By counter emf?
Questions.Answer:
Induced emf is the emf which appears across a conductor when there is relative motion between 
the conductor and a magnetic field; counter emf is the emf induced in a conductor that opposes 
the applied voltage.

Questions.Question: State Lenz's law.
Questions.Answer: The induced emf in any circuit is in a direction to oppose the effect that produced it.

Questions.Question: Why are in-circuit meters used?
Questions.Answer: In-circuit meters are used to monitor the operation of electrical or electronic devices.

Questions.Question: What is one advantage of an out-of-circuit meter when it is compared with an in-circuit meter?
Questions.Answer: Out-of-circuit meters can be used on more than one electrical or electronic device.

Questions.Question: How does a compass react when placed close to a current carrying conductor?
Questions.Answer: The compass needle swings away from magnetic north and aligns itself with the magnetic field

Questions.Question: If the amount of current in the conductor changes, what happens to the magnetic field around the
Questions.Answer:
If the current increases the magnetic field increases; if the current decreases the magnetic field
decreases.

PERMANENT-MAGNET MOVING-COIL MOVEMENT
Questions.Answer: The compass needle will not be deflected as far from magnetic north.

Questions.Question: What type of meter movement is the d’Arsonval meter movement?
Questions.Answer: A permanent-magnet moving-coil meter movement used in most electrical and electronic meters.

Questions.Question: What is the effect of current flow through the coil in a d’Arsonval meter movement?
Questions.Answer:
A magnetic field is generated around the coil and the attraction of this field with the permanent
magnet causes the coil to move.

Questions.Question: What are three functions of the hairsprings in a d’Arsonval meter movement?
Questions.Answer:
To return the pointer to its rest position when there is no current flow; to oppose the coil movement
when there is current flow; to provide electrical connections for the coil.

Questions.Question: How is an ammeter connected to the circuit under test?
How does an ammeter affect the circuit being measured?
Questions.Answer:
Since the ammeter is a resistor in series with the load, it increases the resistance of the circuit and
lowers circuit current.

Questions.Question: How is the ammeter’s effect on the circuit being measured kept to a minimum?
Questions.Answer: The resistance of the ammeter must be much smaller than the circuit load.

Questions.Question: What is ammeter sensitivity?
Questions.Answer: The amount of current that will cause full-scale deflection.

Questions.Question: What is used to allow an ammeter to measure different ranges?

Source: /z/aolney/research_projects/braintrust/materials/NEETS/xhtml/Mod03 - Circuit Protection Control and Measurement.pdf-extracted/Mod03 - Circuit Protection Control and Measurement.pdf.xhtml.json-CHAPTER 1.toparse.ser.json

Questions.Question: Why should you use the highest range of an ammeter for the initial measurement?
Questions.Answer: To prevent damage to the meter movement from excessive current.

Questions.Question: What range of an ammeter is selected for the final measurement?
Questions.Answer: A range that allows a meter reading near the center of the scale.

Questions.Question: List the six safety precautions for the use of ammeters.

Questions.Question: What is a multimeter?
Questions.Answer:
A single measuring device capable of performing the functions of a dc voltmeter and ammeter, an
ac voltmeter and ammeter, and an ohmmeter.

Questions.Question: Why is a multimeter preferred over separate meters?
Questions.Answer:
It is much more convenient to have one meter with several functions than several meters each with
a single function.

Questions.Question: How is a multimeter changed from a voltage measuring device to a resistance measuring device?
Questions.Answer: By changing the position of the function switch.

Questions.Question: Why is the dc scale on a multimeter different than the ac scale?
Questions.Answer: The meter movement reacts to average ac voltage and current and the effective value is desired.

Questions.Question: What is a direct short?
Questions.Answer:
A condition in which some point in the circuit where full system voltage is present comes in
contact with the ground or return side of the circuit.

Questions.Question: What is an excessive current condition?
Questions.Answer:
A condition that is not a direct short but in which circuit current increases beyond the designed
current carrying ability of the circuit.

Questions.Question: What is an excessive heat condition?
Questions.Answer: A condition in which the heat in or around the circuit increases to a higher than normal level

Questions.Question: What are the five main components of a circuit breaker?
Questions.Answer: Frame, operating mechanism, arc extinguishers, terminal connectors, and trip element.

Questions.Question: What are the three types of circuit breaker trip elements?
How does each type of trip element react to an overload?
Questions.Answer:
The thermal trip element makes use of a bimetallic element that bends with an increase in
temperature or current. The bending causes the trip bar to be moved releasing the latch.

Questions.Question: What is a trip-free circuit breaker?
Questions.Answer: A circuit breaker that will trip even if the operating mechanism is held ON.

Questions.Question: What is a nontrip-free circuit breaker?
Questions.Answer: A circuit breaker that can be overridden if the operating mechanism is held ON.

Questions.Question: Where should you use a trip-free circuit breaker?
Questions.Answer: In current sensitive or nonemergency systems.

Questions.Answer: To allow comparisons between conductors of different sizes and resistance.

Questions.Answer: 375 mils (move the decimal three places to the right).

Questions.Question: Define a mil-foot.
Questions.Answer: A circular conductor with a diameter of 1 mil and a length of 1 foot.

Questions.Question: Define a square mil as it relates to a square conductor.
Questions.Answer: The cross-sectional area of a square conductor with a side of 1 mil.

Questions.Answer:

insulation used.

Questions.Question:
What are three types of nonmetallic insulating materials that can be used in a high-temperature 
environments?
Questions.Answer: FEP, extruded polytetrafluoroethylene, and silicone rubber.

conductor when selecting wire size.
Questions.Answer: The heat surrounding the conductor is an important part of total conductor heating.

Questions.Question: State two advantages of using aluminum wire for carrying electricity over long distances.
Questions.Answer: It is light and reduces corona.

Questions.Question: State four advantages of copper over aluminum as a conductor.
Questions.Answer:
It has higher conductivity, it is more ductile, it has relatively high tensile strength, and it can be 
easily soldered.

Questions.Question: Define the temperature coefficient of resistance.
Questions.Answer:
The amount of increase in the resistance of a 1-ohm sample of the conductor per degree of 
temperature rise above 0º C

Questions.Question: Compare the resistance of a conductor to that of an insulator.
Questions.Answer:
Conductors have a very low resistance and insulators have a resistance that is so great that, for 
all practical purposes, they are nonconductors.

Questions.Question: State two fundamental properties of insulating materials.
Define insulation resistance.
Questions.Answer: The resistance to current leakage through the insulation.

Questions.Question: Define dielectric strength.
Questions.Answer: The ability of the insulation material to withstand potential difference.

Questions.Question: How is the dielectric strength of an insulator determined?
Questions.Answer: By raising the voltage on a test sample until it breaks down.

The capacity of the soldering iron to generate and maintain a satisfactory soldering temperature 
while giving up heat to the joint being soldered.

Questions.Question: Why are small-wattage soldering irons not used to solder large conductors?
Questions.Answer: Although its temperature is as high as the larger irons, it does not have thermal inertia.

Questions.Question: State why a well-designed soldering iron is self-regulating.
Questions.Answer:
The resistance of its heating element increases with rising temperature, thus limiting the current 
flow.

Questions.Question: What should be done to a soldering iron tip that is pitted?
Questions.Answer: File the tip until it is smooth and retin it.

Questions.Question: What happens if a soldering gun switch is pressed for periods longer than 30 seconds?
Questions.Answer: It will overheat and could burn the insulation of the wire being soldered.

Questions.Question: What causes the nuts or screws that hold the tips on soldering irons and guns to loosen?
A soldering gun should NOT be used on what components?
Questions.Answer: Electronic components, such as resistors, capacitors, and transistors.

Source: /z/aolney/research_projects/braintrust/materials/NEETS/xhtml/Mod04 - Conductors Wiring and Schematic Reading.pdf-extracted/Mod04 - Conductors Wiring and Schematic Reading.pdf.xhtml.json-CHAPTER 2 .toparse.ser.json

Questions.Question: What is an advantage of using a resistance soldering iron when soldering wire to a connector?
Questions.Answer:
The soldering tips are hot only during the brief period of soldering the connection, thus 
minimizing the chance of burning the wire insulation or connector inserts.

Questions.Question: Why is steel wool NEVER used as an abrasive to clean soldering tools?
Questions.Answer: The strands can fall into electrical equipment being worked on and cause short circuits.

Source: /z/aolney/research_projects/braintrust/materials/NEETS/xhtml/Mod04 - Conductors Wiring and Schematic Reading.pdf-extracted/Mod04 - Conductors Wiring and Schematic Reading.pdf.xhtml.json-CHAPTER 2 .toparse.ser.json

Questions.Question: Why should "antiseize" compound be used on the screw-in tips of the pencil iron?
Questions.Answer: It enables the tip to be removed easily when another is to be inserted.

Questions.Question: If no suitable tip is available for a particular job, how may one be improvised?
Questions.Answer:
Wrap a length of copper wire around one of the regular tips and bend to the proper shape for the 
purpose.

Questions.Question: What two metals are used to from soft solder?

Questions.Answer:
The solder dissolves a small amount of the copper, which combines with the solder forming a new 
alloy; therefore, the joint is one common metal.

Questions.Question: List the five types of transmission lines in use today.
Questions.Answer: Parallel two-wire, twisted pair, shielded pair, coaxial line and waveguide.

Questions.Question: Name two of the three described uses of a two-wire open line.
Questions.Answer: Power lines, rural telephone lines, and telegraph lines.

Questions.Question: What are the two primary disadvantages of a two-wire open line?
Questions.Answer: High radiation losses and noise pickup.

Questions.Question: What type of transmission line is often used to connect a television set to its antenna?
What is the primary advantage of the shielded pair?
Questions.Answer: The conductors are balanced to ground.

Questions.Question: What are the two types of coaxial lines in use today?
What is the chief advantage of the air coaxial line?
Questions.Answer: The ability to minimize radiation losses.

Questions.Question: List the three disadvantages of the air coaxial line.
Questions.Answer:
Expensive to construct, must be kept dry, and high frequency losses limit the practical length of
the line.

Questions.Question: What is the law of reflection?
Questions.Answer: The law of reflection states that the angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection.

Questions.Question: When is the reflection energy the least?
Questions.Answer: When the wave is perpendicular to the reflecting surface.

Questions.Answer: Light will travel faster in an optical material that is less dense.

Questions.Question:
Assume light is traveling through glass, what happens when this light strikes the glass-air
boundary?
Questions.Answer:
Part of the light ray is reflected back into the glass and part of the light ray is refracted (bent) as
it enters the air.

Questions.Question: What condition causes a light ray to be totally reflected back into its medium of propagation?
Questions.Answer:
Total internal reflection occurs when the angle of refraction approaches 90 degrees. This
condition occurs when the angle of incidence increases to the point where no refraction is
possible.

Questions.Question:
LEDs operating at 850 nm provide sufficient optical power for short-distance, low-bandwidth
multimode systems. List three conditions that prevent the use of LEDs in longer distance, higher
bandwidth multimode systems.
Questions.Answer:
Multimode fiber dispersion, the relatively high fiber attenuation, and the LED's relatively low
optical output power.

Questions.Question:
Why can multimode graded-index fiber 1300-nm systems using LEDs operate over longer
distances and at higher bandwidths than 850-nm systems?
Questions.Answer:
Longer distances and higher bandwidths are possible because fiber material losses and
dispersion are significantly reduced at the 1300-nm region.

Questions.Question:
What are the two most common semiconductor materials used in electronic and electro-optic
devices?
What is a laser?
Questions.Answer:
A laser is a device that produces optical radiation using stimulated emission rather than
spontaneous emission.

Questions.Question: .Describe stimulated emission.
Questions.Answer:
A photon initially produced by spontaneous emission in the active region interacts with the laser
material to produce additional photons.

Questions.Question: How does the source drive circuit intensity modulate the source?
Questions.Answer: By varying the current through the source.

Questions.Question: What is a prebias?
Questions.Answer: A current applied in the laser off state just less than the threshold current.

Questions.Question: Which part of the receiver amplifies the electrical signal to a level suitable for further signal

Which performance parameter is the minimum amount of optical power required to achieve a
specific bit-error rate (BER) in digital systems or a given signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) in analog
systems?
Define receiver dynamic range.
Questions.Answer:
The range of optical power levels over which the receiver operates within the specified values. It
usually is described by the ratio of the maximum input power to the sensitivity.

Questions.Question: Describe the operation of an optical detector.
Questions.Answer:
It is a transducer that converts an optical signal into an electrical signal. It does this by
generating an electrical current proportional to the intensity of incident optical radiation.

Questions.Question: For efficient operation, should a detector have a high or low responsivity at the operating
List the two principal optical detectors used in fiber optic systems.
Questions.Answer:
The semiconductor positive-intrinsic-negative (PIN) photodiode and avalanche photodiode
(APD).

Questions.Question: What are the four most common materials used in semiconductor detector fabrication?
Questions.Answer: Silicon, gallium arsenide, germanium, and indium phosphide.

Questions.Question: What is a photocurrent?
Questions.Answer: The current produced when photons are incident on the detector active area.

Questions.Question: Define responsivity.
Questions.Answer:
The ratio of the optical detector's output photocurrent in amperes to the incident optical power in
watts.

Questions.Question: How are PIN photodiodes usually biased?
What is the dark current?
Questions.Answer:
The leakage current that continues to flow through a photodetector when there is no incident
light.

DIGITAL TRANSMISSION
Questions.Answer:
The process of varying one or more characteristics of an optical signal to encode and convey
information.

Questions.Question: What is a digital signal?
Questions.Answer: A discontinuous signal that changes from one state to another in discrete steps.

Questions.Question: In NRZ code, does the presence of a high-light level in the bit duration represent a binary 1 or a
How can the loss of timing occur in NRZ line coding?
Questions.Answer: If long strings of 1s or 0s are present causing a lack of level transitions.

Questions.Question: How is a binary 1 encoded in RZ line coding?
Questions.Answer: A half-period optical pulse present in the first half of the bit duration.

Questions.Question: In Manchester encoding, does a low-to-high light level transition occurring in the middle of the
What is an analog signal?
Questions.Answer:
A continuous signal that varies in a direct proportion to the instantaneous value of a physical
variable.

Questions.Question: What type of modulation do most analog fiber optic communications systems use?

Gist: an optical source whose intensity is a function of a continuous electrical input signal

Questions.Question:
Why has the transmission of video using analog techniques been very popular, especially for
shorter distances?
Questions.Answer: Because cost can be minimized and complex multiplexing and timing equipment is unnecessary.

Questions.Question:
Why is it generally only necessary to refer to point-to-point data links when discussing the
process of fiber optic system design?
Questions.Answer:
Because fiber optic systems that incorporate complex architectures can be simplified into a
collection of point-to-point data links before beginning the design process.
